I would change the discovery of the New World (1492) to prevent the mass genocide and displacement of indigenous populations. The arrival of European explorers led to the colonization of the Americas, which resulted in the loss of land, culture, and life for the indigenous peoples. By preventing this event, the indigenous populations would have continued to thrive and maintain their way of life, and the history of the Americas would be significantly altered.

I would change the outcome of the American Civil War (1861-1865) to prevent the emancipation of enslaved African Americans. The Civil War was fought between the Union (the northern states) and the Confederacy (the southern states) over the issue of slavery. If the Union had won without emancipating the enslaved African Americans, the United States might have continued to be a slave-holding nation, potentially altering the course of racial relations in America.

I would change the outcome of the Renaissance (14th-17th centuries) to prevent the rise of the Medici family and the associated patronage of the arts. The Medici family, particularly Lorenzo de' Medici, was a significant patron of the arts during the Renaissance, commissioning works by artists such as Michelangelo, Leonardo da Vinci, and Raphael. Changing the outcome of the Renaissance would likely have altered the development of the arts and the cultural landscape of Europe.

I would change the outcome of the Battle of Waterloo (June 18, 1815) to prevent the defeat of Napoleon Bonaparte and his subsequent exile to Saint Helena. If Napoleon had emerged victorious, he might have continued to rule France and potentially expanded his empire, altering the course of European history and the political landscape of the continent.

I would change the outcome of the Industrial Revolution (18th-19th centuries) to prevent the rise of factories and the mass production of goods. The Industrial Revolution transformed the way goods were produced, leading to the development of factories and mass production. Changing the outcome of this event would have likely prevented the concentration of wealth and power in the hands of industrialists, potentially altering the social and economic dynamics of the time.
